revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
'''23 Things''', originally called '''Learning 2.0''', is an education and learning project created by Helene Blowers in August 2006.<ref name=cp>{{cite book|last1=Titangos|first1=Hui-Lan|title=Local Community in the Era of Social Media Technologies: A Global Approach|date=2013|publisher=Chandos Publishing|isbn=9781780633619|pages=110–115|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SwFEAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA110&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bertot|first1=John Carlo|last2=Jaeger|first2=Paul T.|last3=McClure|first3=Charles R.|title=Public Libraries and the Internet: Roles, Perspectives, and Implications|date=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781591587767|page=69|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_PGDKr-w4zYC&pg=PA68&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Blowers|first1=Helene|title=10 Tips about 23 Things (originally posted in School Library Journal)|url=http://www.heleneblowers.info/2008/10/10-tips-about-23-things.html|publisher=Helene Blowers|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Blowers, who was then employed as the technology director for the [[Charlotte Mecklenburg Library]],<ref name=L20>{{cite web|last1=Blowers|first1=Helene|title=Learning 2.0|url=http://plcmcl2-about.blogspot.com.au/|publisher=Learning 2.0|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> created the project as a way to encourage librarians to learn and adapt to [[Web 2.0]] and other new technologies.<ref>Maxymuk, John (2008) "23 Things and more", The Bottom Line, Vol. 21 Iss: 2, pp.64 - 66</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Yelton|first1=Andromeda|title=Bridging the Digital Divide with Mobile Services|date=2012|publisher=American Library Association|isbn=9780838958568|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pYlEIUTtXXoC&pg=PA31&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Solomon|first1=Laura|title=The Librarian's Nitty-Gritty Guide to Social Media|date=2012|publisher=American Library Association|isbn=9780838911600|pages=11–12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EfOaAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> The program was loosely based on an article by Stephen Abram, "43 Things I (or You) might want to do this year".<ref name=L20 />
==History== The original format of 23 Things required participants to take part in an eight-and-a-half-week course where they kept up with coursework via a series of weekly blog posts that described Web 2.0.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hemment|first1=Drew|last2=Thompson|first2=Bill|last3=de Vincente|first3=Jose Luis|last4=Cooper|first4=Rachel|title=Digital Public Spaces|date=2013|publisher=Future Everything|isbn=9780956895851|pages=20–21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o3ULz7m1f3UC&pg=RA1-PA2000&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> During this time participants were given 23 assignments (23 things) and were encouraged to work with other learners.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bozarth|first1=Jane|title=Techniques for Enhancing and Extending Learning|date=2010|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-0-470-87766-1|pages=84–85, 91|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xiWi4fuOOl0C&pg=PA84&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> As the project was non-mandatory, participants took part in the coursework by posting their own blog entries for each week's coursework. The project was so successful that Blower held a 23 Things summit in 2009.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bergmann|first1=Julia|last2=Danowski|first2=Patrick|title=Handbuch Bibliothek 2.0|date=2010|publisher=De Gruyter|isbn=9783110232103|page=357|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SpD-kVaDVSwC&pg=PA357&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref>
Since its inception 23 Things has had over 500 iterations and the concept has broadened over time to include learning programs for other professionals and students,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wilkinson|first1=L|last2=Cragg|first2=E|title=23 Things Oxford|url=http://wrap.warwick.ac.uk/38632|publisher=SCONUL Focus|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Gwyer|first1=Roisin|last2=Stubbings|first2=Ruth|last3=Walton|first3=Graham|title=The Road to Information Literacy: Librarians as facilitators of learning|date=2012|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=3110281015|page=235|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arrQAVi0SzoC&pg=PA235&dq=%2223+Things%22+blowers&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V_MIVfC8LYuigwSMjoPgBw&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%2223%20Things%22%20blowers&f=false|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> and has also expanded to include more than 23 topics. 23 Things has also expanded beyond the United States and is currently used in multiple countries including [[Australia]] and New Zealand.<ref>14</ref><ref name=IFLA>{{cite web|last1=Stephens|first1=Michael|title="23 Things" as Transformative Learning|url=http://conference.ifla.org/past-wlic/2012/150-stephens-en.pdf|publisher=IFLA|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> Currently, "23 Things"is a term used to describe a Web immersion experience for participants primarily supported by the participants themselves, where they are actively involved in a network of peers and colleagues, using digital communication tools, and using a blog to post reflections as they learn.<ref name=cp />
==Research== In 2012 [[San Jose State University]] assistant professor Michael Stephens performed a research study of 23 Things programs in Australia. He found that even if people did not successfully complete the program, that the program still had the potential to positively impact library staff as the participants would still be likely to use what they did learn and/or to return to the program at a later date.<ref name=IFLA /> Stephens also noted that a strong majority of those who completed said they felt confident exploring and using new technologies: confidence and curiosity were identified as particularly notable outcomes.<ref name=IFLA />
==See also== *[[43 Things]]
== References == {{Reflist}} 14. Lindsay, Lucie. [http://conference.deanz.org.nz/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/DEANZ16-Conference-proceedings11-April.pdf#page=170 "What makes a course like 23 Things go viral?." There and back: Charting flexible pathways in open, mobile and distance education] (2016): 170.
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Julia|last2=Leslie|first2=Lyn|title=Twenty‐three steps to learning Web 2.0 technologies in an academic library|journal=The Electronic Library|date=2008|volume=26|issue=6|pages=790–802|doi=10.1108/02640470810921583|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/02640470810921583|accessdate=18 March 2015}} *{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Julia|last2=Leslie|first2=Lyn|title=Learning 2.0: a catalyst for library organisational change|journal=The Electronic Library|date=2010|volume=28|issue=5|pages=657–668|doi=10.1108/02640471011081942|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/02640471011081942|accessdate=18 March 2015}} *{{cite journal|last1=Titangos|first1=Hui‐Lan H.|last2=Mason|first2=Gail L.|title=Learning Library 2.0: 23 Things @SCPL|journal=Library Management|date=2009|volume=30|issue=1/2|pages=44–56|doi=10.1108/01435120910927510|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/01435120910927510|accessdate=18 March 2015}}
== External links == * [https://plcmcl2-about.blogspot.com.au/ The original 23 Things] * [http://www.heleneblowers.info/ Helene Blowers blog] * [http://open-inform.info/2015/03/nature-of-23-things/ The Nature of 23 Things] * [http://delicious.com/hblowers/learning2.0libraries List of 500+ programs replicated from the original 23 Things (Helene Blowers' Delicious bookmarks)]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
In a [[storytelling|story]], we detect an '''''allotopy''''' when two basic meaning traits ([[Seme (semantics)|seme]]s) contradict each other, that is when they trace two incompatible interpretations. It was conceived as being the opposite of an [[Isotopy (semiotics)|isotopy]], which is the homogeneity resulting from repetition of the same seme.<ref name="KlinkenbergAllodef">[[Jean-Marie Klinkenberg]] (1996) ''Précis de sémiotique générale'', De Boeck, p. 118 [http://www.info-metaphore.com/definition/isotopie.html]</ref> This concept has been coined in the 1970s by the Belgian semioticians known as ''[[Groupe µ]]''.
==History== In the 1970, the Belgian semioticians known under the name ''[[Groupe µ]]'', introduced the concept of Allotopy.<ref>[http://www.info-metaphore.com/definition/allotopie.html Définition de : l'allotopie]</ref> They first discussed the concept in publications like ''Isotopie et allotopie'',<ref>DUBOIS J. ; EDELINE F. ; KLINKENBERG J.-M. ; MINGUET P. (1976) ''[http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=12751413 Isotopie et allotopie: le fonctionnement rhétorique du texte]'', no14, pp. 41-65 (2 p.)</ref> ''Isotopie, allotopie et polytopie'' (1976),<ref>Groupe µ (1976) ''Isotopie, allotopie et polytopie : le texte rhétorique'', Versus, 14, 1 976</ref> and ''A Rhetoric of Poetry'' (1977).<ref>Groupe µ (1977)</ref>
==Allotopy and humor== ''[[Groupe µ]]'' discussed the relation of allotopy to [[jokes]] and [[humor]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} [[Salvatore Attardo]], despite not using the term allotopy, formulated a theory of humor based on the idea of the "incompatible interpretations", called the [[isotopy-disjunction model]].<ref>[[Salvatore Attardo]] (2001) ''Humorous texts: a semantic and pragmatic analysis'', sect.5.3.2, p.83</ref><ref>[[Salvatore Attardo]] (1994) ''Linguistic theories of humor'', chap.2</ref> This is part of the broader idea of defining humor as based on [[contradiction]]/[[wikt:incongruity|incongruity]].
==See also== *[[Allotopic syntagm]]<ref>''[http://www.reference-global.com/doi/abs/10.1515/semi.1996.111.1-2.1 The sign in Paris semiotics]'', [[Semiotica]]. Volume 111, Issue 1-2, Pages 1–34, ISSN (Online) 1613-3692, ISSN (Print) 0037-1998, {{doi|10.1515/semi.1996.111.1-2.1}}, //1996</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *[[Groupe µ]] (1977) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=zllZAAAAMAAJ Rhétorique de la poésie: lecture linéaire, lecture tabulaire]''. [http://swbplus.bsz-bw.de/bsz006320201inh.pdf Original summary] in French
==Further reading== *[[Jean-Marie Klinkenberg|Klinkenberg]] ''et al.'' (2008) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=UyeIkQQIL3EC Figures de la figure: Sémiotique et rhétorique générale]'' *[[Serge Botet]] (2008) ''Petit traité de la métaphore: Un panorama des théories modernes de la métaphore'' *[[François Rastier]] (1987) ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20140221075307/http://www.puf.com/Wiki/Autres_Collections:S%C3%A9mantique_interpr%C3%A9tative Sémantique interprétative]'', chapter VI ''Isotopies minimales'', section 2 ''Isotopies génériques'' and section 4 ''Degres d'allotopie specifique'' *Paul Delbouille, Françoise Tilkin ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=oMxXYjc6OxcC Le lire et le délire:]'' recueil offert à Paul Delbouille par ses collègues, pp. 223–45
==External links== *[http://www.info-metaphore.com/definition/allotopie.html Définition de : l'allotopie] {{fr-icon}} *[http://www.info-metaphore.com/articles/klinkenberg-argumentation-dans-la-figure.html L'argumentation dans la figure (J.-M. Klinkenberg)] {{fr-icon}}
[[Category:Semiotics]]

revision.text:
'''Body image law''' is the developing area of law that, according to Dr Marilyn Bromberg of the [[University of Western Australia]] Law School and Cindy Halliwell, a law student at [[Deakin University]], "encompasses the bills, laws and government actions (such as establishing parliamentary inquiries and creating policies) that may help to improve the [[body image]] of the general public, and particularly of young people".<ref name="mb/ch">{{cite journal|last1=Bromberg|first1=Marilyn|last2=Halliwell|first2=Cindy|title=All About That Bass’ and Photoshopping a Model’s Waist: Introducing Body Image Law|journal=The University of Notre Dame Australia Law Review|date=2016|volume=18|url=http://researchonline.nd.edu.au/undalr/vol18/iss1/1/|accessdate=5 November 2017}}</ref> Among the reasons for implementing law in this area is to prevent the images of unhealthily thin women causing poor body image which can, along with other factors, lead to an [[eating disorder]].<ref name="mb/ch" />
== Laws == The [[Israeli system of government|Israeli government]] passed a body image law in 2012 which became operational the following year. The law requires models to have a minimum [[body mass index]] to work and if an image was photoshopped to make the model appear thinner, it must have a warning. The warning must state that the image was modified and it must take up at least seven percent of the image. Breaches can result in a civil lawsuit.<ref name="loc">{{cite web|title=Israel: Restrictions on Depiction of Underweight Models in Commercials|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/israel-restrictions-on-depiction-of-underweight-models-in-commercials/|website=www.loc.gov|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=en|date=26 March 2012}}</ref>
The [[French Government]] passed a similar law in 2015 which came into effect in 2017. This law requires that models provide their employers with a "medical certificate, valid for up to two years, confirming their general physical well-being and the fact that they are not excessively underweight." <ref name="Friedman">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/08/fashion/france-laws-thin-models.html|title=A New Age in French — Modeling|last=Friedman|first=Vanessa|date=2017-05-08|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The BMI of models older than 16 will also be taken into consideration, when determining their overall health.<ref name="Friedman"/>
In contrast to the Israeli law, breaching it attracts criminal sanctions.<ref name="vf">{{cite news|last1=Friedman|first1=Vanessa|title=A New Age in French — Modeling|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/08/fashion/france-laws-thin-models.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 May 2017}}</ref> Additionally, any photo that has been digitally altered must be labeled as such; failure to label these photos will result in a "fine of 37,500 euros, or more than $41,000," and hiring a model without the verified medical certificate and requirements "carries a fine of €75,000 and six months in jail." <ref name="Friedman"/> The law dictates that digitally altered images must be labeled "applies only to advertising, not to editorial images in magazines or newspapers." <ref name="Friedman"/>
The [[Greater London Authority]] banned advertisements that promote unhealthy body image on [[Transport for London]] public transport in 2016.<ref name="ap/mo">{{cite news|title=London mayor bans Tube ads that promote unhealthy body image|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-3640626/London-mayor-takes-aim-body-shaming-advertising-Tube.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=[[Mail Online]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=14 June 2016}}</ref> Similarly, [[Trondheim]] in Norway banned advertisements that promote unhealthy body image in public places in 2017.<ref name="gs">{{cite news|last1=Samuels|first1=Gabriel|title=Norwegian city bans adverts featuring semi-nude models|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/norway-trondheim-ban-adverts-semi-naked-models-negative-body-image-a7026421.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|date=12 May 2016}}</ref>
The [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]]'s position in this area is that it is up to industry to solve the problem of poor body image.<ref name="jw">{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Jessica|title=Skinny models: Australia welcomes Paris ban|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/fashion/skinny-models-australia-welcomes-paris-ban-20150319-1m36t7.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=19 March 2015}}</ref> Likewise, the previous Labor Government created a non-binding Voluntary Industry Code of Conduct on Body Image.<ref name="apo">{{cite web|title=Voluntary industry code of conduct on body image|url=http://apo.org.au/node/21888|publisher=Analysis & Policy Observatory|accessdate=5 November 2017|date=1 July 2010}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Law]] [[Category:Health law]] [[Category:Public health]] [[Category:Discrimination]] [[Category:Body shape]]
{{law-stub}}

[[File:Bumblebees.jpg|thumb|Two bumblebees foraging on a flower, taken at Bariloche, Argentina]]
[[Bumblebees]] (''Bombus'' spp.), like the [[honeybee]] (''Apis'' spp.) collect nectar and pollen from flowers and store them for food. Many individuals must be recruited to forage for food to provide for the hive. Some bee species have highly developed ways of communicating with each other about the location and quality of food resources ranging from physical to chemical displays. Honey bees are known for their specialized dances, such as the [[waggle dance]] which recruit other bees to the precise location of the food source.<ref name="Winston">Winston ML, 1987. The biology of the honey bee. Cambridge: Harvard University Press.</ref> Bumblebees are not capable of transmitting this type of detailed information. Instead, the nest serves as a hub where bees receive information about the foraging bouts of her conspecifics.<ref name=" Dornhaus ">{{cite journal | last1 = Dornhaus | first1 = A. | last2 = Chittka | first2 = L. | year = 2004 | title = Information flow and regulation of foraging activity in bumble bees | url = | journal = Apidologie | volume = 35 | issue = | pages = 183–192 | doi=10.1051/apido:2004002}}</ref> Differences between the communication methods of honeybees and bumblebees are mainly due to differences in colony size and nest structure.<ref name=" Winston " /> Bumblebees are distinct from honeybees because they lack receiver bees (bees in the nest which receive pollen and nectar from incoming foragers during unloading) and are not capable of [[trophallaxis]] (the transfer of nectar from one bee to another). They deposit collected nectar directly into the honey pots and don't share information of the quality of the resource with other bees through nectar transfer.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2" /> Another bee may sample the nectar brought into the nest, and if the colony is in need of food or the nectar is high quality she will likely go out foraging herself.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2">Dornhaus A and Chittka L. 2005. Bumble bees (Bombus terrestris) store both food and information in honeypots. Behavioural Ecology. 16:661-666.</ref> Other means of alerting passive bees to a potentially rewarding resource include releasing pheromone signals and increasing physical activity.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2" /> For information on communication methods in honey bees, see [[Bee learning and communication]].
==Pioneer research== [http://www.dornhaus.de/ Anna Dornhaus] ([[University of Arizona]]) and [http://chittkalab.sbcs.qmul.ac.uk/Chittka.html [[Lars Chittka]]] ([[Queen Mary University of London]]) began publishing their findings on the communication systems of bumblebees in 1999 when Ms. Dornhaus was an MSc. student in the [http://chittkalab.sbcs.qmul.ac.uk/ Chittka lab].<ref name=" Anna's ">"Anna's past and current research projects." Anna's Homepage. N.p., n.d. Web. 10 Apr. 2011. http://www.dornhaus.de/www.anna/aprojects.html</ref> Their next major paper on the food alert system in bumblebees came in 2001 probing the potential evolutionary mechanisms of forager recruitment in a bumblebee nest.<ref name=" Food alert ">{{cite journal | last1 = Dornhaus | first1 = A | last2 = Chittka | first2 = L | year = 2001 | title = Food alert in bumblebees, Bombus terrestris: possible mechanisms and evolutionary implications | url = | journal = Behav Ecol Sociobiol | volume = 50 | issue = | pages = 570–576 | doi=10.1007/s002650100395}}</ref> In 2004 they, along with A. Brockmann (University of Wuzburg) published another paper regarding the pheromone released by bees upon returning to the nest and the type of information it provides other bees.<ref name=" tergal glands ">{{cite journal | last1 = Dornhaus | first1 = A | last2 = Brockmann | first2 = A | last3 = Chittka | first3 = L | year = 2003 | title = Bumblebees alert to food with pheromone from tergal glands | url = | journal = J Comp Physiol A | volume = 189 | issue = | pages = 47–51 }}</ref>
==Monitoring honey pots== [[File:Bumblebee nest.jpg|thumb|Bumblebee nest with full visible honey pots]]
A bumblebee nest differs in size and structure from that of a honeybee. Bumblebee nests are smaller and contain far fewer individuals which is mostly due to differences in the method of colony reproduction.<ref name=" Winston " /> Honeybee colonies can contain up to 20000 individuals whereas bumblebee colonies usually only contain a few hundred.<ref name=" Winston " /> This means the number of bees available for foraging is low and resources must be allocated accordingly. Assessing the level of food stores is not seen in honeybees, likely because the large colonies make such assessment inefficient.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2" /> Bumblebees only store enough honey for a few days.<ref name=" Heinrich ">Heinrich B, 1979. Bumblebee economics. Cambridge: Harvard University Press</ref> By monitoring the levels of the honey pots a bumblebee colony can either up or down regulate the number of bees out foraging.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2" /> Lab experiments by Anna Dornhaus and [[Lars Chittka]] in 2005 showed evidence of this up or down regulation by monitoring the activity level of the hive after the addition of 'nectar' to the honey pots. Hive activity increased when high quality nectar was injected into the honey pots, provided the wells weren't already full. When the honey pots were full, there was no significant change in activity regardless of whether the nectar imported was from a high or low quality source.<ref name=" Dornhaus 2" /> They hypothesized that either the foraging bee does not signal the nest or the nest bees ignore the signal because the demand for food is low. The tropical bumblebee ''[[Bombus transversalis]]'' has also been shown to respond to honey pot levels in a similar way.<ref name=" Cameron ">{{cite journal | last1 = Dornhaus | first1 = A | last2 = Cameron | first2 = S | year = 2003 | title = A scientific note on food alert in Bombus transversalis | url = | journal = Apidologie | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 87–88 | doi=10.1051/apido:2002045}}</ref>
==Excited runs== Honeybees have very controlled patterns of movement, such as the waggle or tremble dance which serve to deliver specific coordinates of fruitful sources to potential foragers. Bumblebee movement is comparatively random and does not supply coordinates to other bees.<ref name=" Food alert " /> Other experiments by Dornhaus and [[Lars Chittka|Chittka]] (2001) showed increased movement of successful foraging bees upon returning to the nest. Successful bees ran faster and longer compared to unsuccessful bees. A bee may spend several minutes running around the nest before flying out again.<ref name=" Food alert " /> As the bee runs, it has been hypothesized that the bee may also offer a form of communication based on the buzzing sounds made from her wings.<ref name=" Anna's " /> These 'excited' runs serve in part to rouse other bees into foraging.<ref name=" Food alert " />
==Pheromones==
=== Pheromone distribution === Bumblebees produce a signalling pheromone from tergal glands located on their dorsal abdomen as discovered in experiments performed by A. Dornhaus, A. Brockmann and [[Lars Chittka|L. Chittka]] in 2003. They monitored the activity of bee colonies after exposure to products from several glands located along the bee's body. The only one yielding significant changes in activity level came from the tergites VI and VII.<ref name=" tergal glands" /> This is similar to a pheromone produced from the Nasanov gland in honeybees, but differs in the active compound.<ref name=" tergal glands" /> It has been suggested that this pheromone may facilitate learning of floral scents, since its release is coupled with the import of the floral scent from the nectar collected by the successful forager.<ref name=" tergal glands" /> Experiments by Molet, [[Lars Chittka|Chittka]] and Raine in 2009 showed that bumblebees may be able to learn floral scents associated with rewarding flowers better if the particular scent is found in nectar deposited in the honeypots.<ref name="Molet">{{cite journal | last1 = Molet | first1 = M | authorlink2 = Lars Chittka | last2 = Chittka | first2 = L | last3 = Raine | first3 = NE | year = 2009 | title = How floral odours are learned inside the bumblebee (Bombus terrestris) nest | url = | journal = Naturwissenschaften | volume = 96 | issue = | pages = 213–219 | doi=10.1007/s00114-008-0465-x | pmid=18949450}}</ref>
=== Brood recognition pheromones === Many bumblebee species have been observed to use pheromones in the process of brood recognition. In the species ''[[Yellow-faced bumblebee|Bombus vosnesenskii]]'', brood recognition, and subsequently, brood clump incubation, has been shown to be pheromone induced. Queens will deposit chemical signals on a brood clump to help herself and her workers identify the eggs. However, these pheromones appear to be species' specific, as opposed to specific to individual queens, as queens will also incubate the eggs of conspecific bees.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Pheromone Induced Brooding Behavior in Bombus vosnesenskii and B. edwardsii (Hymenoptera: Bombidae)|jstor = 25082666|journal = Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society|date = 1974-07-01|pages = 396–404|volume = 47|issue = 3|first = Bernd|last = Heinrich}}</ref>
=== Queen pheromones === As in other social Hymenoptera,<ref name="VanOystaeyen">{{Cite journal|title = Conserved Class of Queen Pheromones Stops Social Insect Workers from Reproducing|url = http://science.sciencemag.org/content/343/6168/287|journal = Science|date = 2014-01-17|pages = 287–290|volume = 343|issue = 6168|first = Annette|last = Van Oystaeyen|display-authors=etal|doi=10.1126/science.1244899|pmid=24436417}}</ref> bumblebee queens have also been shown to release characteristic pheromones to signal their presence and stop the workers from reproducing. In ''[[Buff-tailed bumblebee|Bombus terrestris]]'', for example, two studies have shown that workers resorbed oocytes more often<ref name="VanOystaeyen" /> and had fewer developing oocytes in their ovaries<ref name="Holman2014">{{Cite journal|title = Bumblebee size polymorphism and worker response to queen pheromone|pmc = 4184022|journal = PeerJ|date = 2014-09-30|pages = e604|volume = 2|first = Luke|last = Holman|doi=10.7717/peerj.604|pmid=25289189}}</ref> after treatment with the queen-characteristic cuticular hydrocarbon pentacosane. Similar activity of queen-specific cuticular hydrocarbons has also been documented in ''[[Common eastern bumblebee|Bombus impatiens]]'',<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Conserved queen pheromones in bumblebees|url = https://doi.org/10.7287/peerj.preprints.2003v1|journal = PeerJ Preprints|date = 2016-04-26|pages = e2003v1|volume = 4|first = Luke|last = Holman|display-authors=etal|doi=10.7287/peerj.preprints.2003v1}}</ref> as well as in several other species of ants and wasps.<ref name="VanOystaeyen" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Bumblebees]] [[Category:Animal communication]]

page.title: Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology

revision.text:
{{Infobox institute |name = Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology |image = |image_name = Institute for Genomic Biology, University of Illinois Campus July 2013.jpg |image_size =250px |image_alt = |caption = The Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology, with the [[Morrow Plots]] in the foreground |latin_name = |motto = |founder = |established =2006 |mission =To advance life sciences research and stimulate bioeconomic development in the state of Illinois. |focus =Transformative research in systems biology, cellular and metabolic engineering and genome technology. |president = |chairman = |head_label = Director |head = [[Gene E. Robinson]] |faculty = |adjunct_faculty = |staff = |key_people = |budget = |endowment = |debt = |num_members = |subsidiaries = |owner = |non-profit_slogan = |former_name = |location = |city = Urbana |state = Illinois |province = |country = United States of America |coor = |address = 1206 W Gregory Drive |website = http://www.igb.illinois.edu/ |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
The '''Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology''' ('''IGB''') is an interdisciplinary facility for [[genomics]] research at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]. The construction of the IGB, which was completed in 2006, represented a strategy to centralize biotechnology research at the University of Illinois. A goal of the IGB is to provide a collaborative environment in which researchers with diverse backgrounds are drawn together by their pursuit of scientific questions related to genomics. The interdisciplinary nature of the institute promotes the creation of innovative solutions to societal challenges related to health, the environment, and food production. Current research at the IGB explores the genomic bases of a wide range of phenomena, including the progression of cancer, the ecological impact of global change, tissue and organ growth, and the diversity of animal behavior.<ref name=igbweb>{{cite web|title=The Institute for Genomic Biology: Where science meets society.|url=http://www.igb.illinois.edu|accessdate=2013-06-10}}</ref>
==History==
===Construction=== Plans for what would become the Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology (IGB) were formed in the late 1990s.<ref name="igbweb" /> Initially, the facility was to be named the Post-Genomic Institute; the name was changed to Institute for Genomic Biology in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tallon|first=Mary|title=U. Illinois trustees approve health benefits for same-sex partners.|newspaper=Daily Illini|date=2003-07-18}}</ref> Funds of $67.5 million were initially appropriated by the state of Illinois for construction in 2000.<ref name=aps1stfunding>{{cite news|title=Governor expected to unveil $1 billion technology initiative.|newspaper=Associated Press Services|date=2000-01-29}}</ref> In response to economic hardships, the state halted plans for construction in 2001 as part of a large set of budget cuts,<ref name=stlouis>{{cite news|last=McDermott|first=Kevin|title=Ryan pares $219 million from Illinois budget.|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=2001-11-28}}</ref> but in 2002, funds were re-appropriated.<ref name=midconst>{{cite news|title=State gives U. of I. $123 million for tech buildings.|newspaper=Midwest Construction|date=December 2002}}</ref> Construction began in April 2004 and was completed in November 2006. The building was dedicated in March 2007.<ref name="igbweb" /> The Institute, initially named the Institute for Genomic Biology, officially changed its name to the Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology in 2015 to honor the scientific contributions of [[Carl Woese]].
===Leadership=== The IGB was initially led by [[Harris Lewin]], then a professor in the Department of Animal Sciences at the University of Illinois. Lewin served as the founding director until 2011, when he accepted the position of Research Vice Chancellor at [[University of California, Davis]]. [[Gene E. Robinson]], a professor in the Entomology department, took over as Interim Director, and was named the new Director of IGB in January 2012.<ref name="igbweb" />
==Research==
===Personnel=== The IGB houses over 130 faculty and 600+ graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and research personnel. IGB faculty are drawn from a broad range of departments, including Crop Sciences, Psychology, Entomology, Physics and Computer Science.<ref name="igbweb" />
===Aims=== The research goals of the IGB fall under one of three Program Areas ([[Systems Biology]], [[Biological engineering|Cellular]] and [[Metabolic engineering|Metabolic Engineering]], and Genome Technology). Work at the IGB addresses societal challenges related to health, the environment, and food production, both through basic science research and through exploration of ethical and legal issues. Research is further organized into Themes, each of which occupies a customized lab and office space. Each Theme contains multiple research groups. These groups often pursue some research questions independently, but are unified by a common interest in the broader area of the Theme. The multi-group space encourages communication and collaboration between researchers with diverse backgrounds and technical skills. One senior faculty member acts as Theme leader, and is responsible for shaping and guiding the overall research initiative. Themes are reviewed every five years; new Themes may be added or existing Themes modified to reflect the current state of genomics research. Current Themes are listed below:<ref name="igbweb" />
{|style width="90%" border="1" class="wikitable" |+ Research Themes at the Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology ! Theme ! Theme Leader ! Description of Research |- ! Anticancer Discovery from Pets to People (ACPP) | Paul Hergenrother || Discovers and develops novel anticancer agents for the treatment of companion animal and human patients. |- ! Biocomplexity (BCXT) |style="width: 11%;"| [[Nigel Goldenfeld]] || style="width: 45%;" |Develops quantitative techniques for the description and study of natural phenomena on many levels, from single molecules to ecosystems. |- ! Biosystems Design (BSD) | [[Huimin Zhao]] || Develops tools to efficiently and systematically control gene expression in eukaryotic cells, technology with potential applications in medicine, food crop improvement and biofuel production. |- ! Computing Genomes for Reproductive Health (CGRH) | Derek Wildman || Identifies molecular mechanisms contributing to preterm birth and other disorders of pregnancy. |- ! Genomic Ecology of Global Change (GEGC) | Donald Ort || Examines how alterations in carbon uptake and release in organisms exposed to aspects of global climate change are mediated by gene networks. |- ! Gene Networks in Neural and Developmental Biology (GNDP) | Lisa Stubbs || Investigates the conserved gene networks that may support commonalities in behavior across diverse animal species, and how differences in those networks contribute to behavioral differences between species. |- ! Mining Microbial Genomes (MMG) | William Metcalf || Characterizes the functions and properties of microbial gene products and metabolites, in an effort to discover molecules with novel and useful chemical properties. |- ! Regenerative Biology and Tissue Engineering (RBTE) | Brendan Harley || Investigates the properties of tissue growth, and develops technologies to replace or regenerate tissues or organs that have been affected by medical conditions. |- ! Energy Biosciences Institute (EBI){{efn|Rather than a traditional Theme, the Energy Biosciences Institute is an externally funded research institute. See [[Institute for Genomic Biology#Notable awards and partnerships|Notable awards and partnerships]].}} | Chris Somerville{{efn|Professor of Alternative Energy at the University of California, Berkeley and Director of the Energy Biosciences Institute. Isaac Cann, a professor in the Department of Microbiology and Animal Sciences at the University of Illinois, is Deputy Director.}} || Seeks to develop and improve sources of two major types of [[bioenergy]]—[[non-food crop]]s and fossil-fuel microbiology—in part through investigation of the genomic specializations of the organisms involved in each. |}
==Notable awards and partnerships==
In 2007, the University of Illinois, along with the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California]], became partners with the energy company [[BP]] as part of a major research project to develop bioenergy sources. The University of Illinois facility is based in the IGB.<ref name=bpnews>{{cite news|last=Mercer|first=David|title=Two U.S. universities chosen by BP for partnership in alternative-fuels research.|newspaper=Associated Press Worldstream|date=2007-02-01}}</ref>
In 2011, Abbott Nutrition and the University of Illinois formed collaboration to establish a research center for the study of the relationship between [[nutrition and cognition]], the [http://cnlm.illinois.edu/ Center for Nutrition, Learning, and Memory] (CNLM). Several campus units are currently partners of CNLM, including the IGB.<ref name=cnlm>{{cite news|last=des Garennes|first=Christine|title=University of Illinois, Abbott developing nutrition, cognition research center.|newspaper=The News-Gazette|date=2011-12-22}}</ref>
==Building==
The IGB is located on the south side of the University of Illinois main campus at Urbana-Champaign. The building was constructed by the architecture firm CUH2A (now a part of the architecture-engineering company HDR). The exterior of the building was designed to include elements of [[Georgian architecture]], consistent with many other campus buildings, but with a modern feel.<ref name=cu2ha>{{cite news|title=Award winning Institute for Genomic Biology designed by CUH2A opens at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.|newspaper=Business Wire|date=2007-04-18}}</ref> Inside, each Research Theme has a large, [[open plan]] laboratory space and additional work rooms and office and meeting area.<ref name="igbweb" /> The building stands adjacent to the Morrow Plots.
==See also==
*[[Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology]] *[[Carl Woese]] *[[Coordinated Science Laboratory]] *[[Gene E. Robinson]] *[[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] *[[Lawrence B. Schook]]

==References== {{Reflist}}
